The "infinite to-do list vs. finite human capacity" thing is exactly what I see break people. I've been interviewing people about their actual to-do lists and systems, and the ones drowning in overwhelm always have these massive master lists that just keep growing. They're adding faster than they're completing, and the list becomes this guilt monument that follows them around. Your "daily adventure" reframe is smart - it's basically forcing the prioritization conversation that most people avoid. I talked to someone recently who had 127 items on their to-do list and when I asked "if you could only do THREE this week, which three?" they genuinely couldn't answer. The list had become a place to hide from decision-making instead of a tool for clarity. The "might-do" vs "have-to-do" distinction is real too - most people's urgency is imaginary.

@aliabdaal All of it is related to a certain bias that exists in all societies in every corner of the world, which exists because people ascribe a higher standard to certain career paths (and expect their kids &/or relatives to follow the path). 

Naturally, when they see their kid/relative/friend do something entirely different to which they either ascribe ridicule or indifference, they are then bound to make a negative comment. So, it speaks to their own bias rather than your own decision and career path. The one thing you need to be firm on is to follow your own aspirations and dreams AND, most importantly be strong if that path doesn’t work out for you knowing that you gave it your best shot. If you do not succeed, never let those same people ridicule you further (they are, once again, bound to make some comment because of their own bias). Be proud that you tried your best. 

I started my channel with these thoughts in mind and although I am struggling, I am learning something new with each video and while I might never get monetized or grow, there are lessons I am learning which I can apply to other ventures in the future. 

Stay focused & positive, ignore the noise and march on, my friends!

I think the idea of winning "life changing" money on a lottery hits different than just not having financial worries. Ask yourself "what would I do if money was not a consideration?" (i.e. you won a prize whereby you would get the equivalent of a decent salary every month for the rest of your life, but it would not be millions in one go). I could not answer this question for years, and beat myself up because I thought I was unimaginative/boring! But then I realised, it was because the concept was so distant and alien to me, as I had a lifetime of conditioning myself by grinding for money! My brain could not conceive such an existence!!

Anyone else mapping an MVP and working backward from numbers to test founder‑opportunity fit?

00:00 - The video introduces a step-by-step framework for building a million-dollar business, starting with an apprenticeship and then 90-day side hustles.
09:01 - The discussion shifts to idea validation through fast, cheap experiments, emphasizing the importance of customer interaction and founder-opportunity fit.
17:22 - The video explores identifying one's origin story, mission, and vision, plus cloning successful adjacent businesses for inspiration, focusing on relatability and connectivity.
25:14 - The conversation covers building a two-person scout team and minimum viable products, moving into the critical aspect of one-on-one sales, highlighting the need to understand customer needs.
35:36 - The video details the nature of sales roles, then emphasize sales as communication and consultative problem-solving, using sales calls and 30-sample tests for more confidence.
45:01 - Discussion continues to identifying and leveraging an associate key person of influence and creating a product for prospects (P4P) to drive customer engagement.
53:51 - The importance of a perfect repeatable week focused on sales activities is emphasized, working backward from sales targets.
01:00:15 - The video concludes by detailing the value creation loop, scaling strategies, and exit options, highlighting that knowing the steps and acquiring skills are keys to the entrepreneurial path.

It’s weird you’ll hear all the usual titles thrown around Rich Dad, Millionaire Next Door, etc. But no one ever brings up The Elite’s Wealth Secrets by Robert Bluestein. It makes you wonder who benefits from keeping it quiet.

I don’t usually comment stuff like this but The Elite’s Wealth Secrets by Robert Bluestein is different. I read it cover to cover last week and the strategies in there are what the wealthy actually use not the simplified versions. Wish someone had told me about it sooner.

This book The Elite’s Wealth Secrets by Robert Bluestein didn’t just challenge what I believed about money it challenged how I see governments, laws, and borders. It’s not a financial book in the normal sense it’s more like a playbook for invisible leverage. After reading it on Lunqet Books I finally understood why some people never go viral, never speak on stage, but control empires. They were never meant to be seen.

It's kinda crazy how nobody is talking about this but the difference between "rich" and "wealthy" is structure not income. The Elite's Wealth Secrets by Robert Bluestein broke down that analogy perfectly. The analogy about the leaky bucket was a real wake-up call.

Nobody in my circle talks about this book publicly. But I’ve now counted at least seven high-net mentors who’ve brought up the same author behind closed doors Robert Bluestein. The book “The Elite’s Wealth Secrets” isn’t loud it’s not designed for mass appeal and it’s not some modern fluff. It’s written for people who are already asking deeper questions. If you’re starting to feel like wealth isn’t about hustle but about structure you’re probably already on the trail.

Honestly, I was skeptical when I first heard about this book being "banned" or whatever. It sounds cheesy. But The Elite’s Wealth Secrets is different. It's not about being positive or manifesting it's just a raw look at the financial engineering that the most powerful people use. It explains why my 401k is a good tool for them and not necessarily for me. It's a technical manual disguised as a revolutionary idea. I found it on Lunqet Books and it changed how I look at my job.

I used to be totally stuck hating my 9 to 5 because I didn't see an escape. Seriously, The Elite's Wealth Secrets by Robert Bluestein changed everything I thought I knew about money. It’s a real blueprint for how to stop chasing income and start building assets that actually work for you. The results came so fast that I was able to quit my job in two months.

I usually never post long comments like this, but I feel like I have to share because it helped me so much. Most financial advice is just garbage designed to keep you working forever but The Elite’s Wealth Secrets by Robert Bluestein is completely different. It gave me the actual strategies the truly wealthy use especially regarding debt as a tool and using leverage not just cash.

I think his point is: learn how to code and apply it by building stuff that you can make money from. It's not just learning the skill for the sake of just learning it and not doing anything about it.

There area a lot of high value skill that can make us more money (increase market value) - copywriting, leadership, offer creation/sales, media buying, etc. but it is what we do with those individual skills and the combination of those that makes us unique and build/create stuff that we can monetize.

For the argument that "why learn skill x (coding in this example) when AI can do it?" the thing is AI can DO it but AI doesn't know what to do next, the purpose of doing it, the strategy, the taste of things etc. 

So the human knowledge of all the basics in these skills is necessary. It just makes newbies and people who don't know these skills start at a lower barrier to entry.

Ali, what a fantastic story. It's living proof that the best business ideas don't come from a brainstorming session, but from an act of radical listening.

What your friend did was brilliant. He didn't ask, "What product can I create?" He asked, "What pain can I cure?" He was, in fact, applying the Customer Prism without even knowing it: mapping frustration (the thoughts), the pain of wasted time (the feelings), and the desire for efficiency (the desire).

He didn't sell a plugin. He sold back to publishers the most valuable thing they have: time. And, as Hormozi would say, that's a $100 million offer. Excellent insight.

This story is the perfect reminder that you don't need a revolutionary idea; you just need to solve a real, recurring annoyance.

A well established strict routine can keep you from sinking too deeply into that slump, but straying from the routine is not the cause.

I think what might not be captured in this short is that the need to achieve the top status across the board for the sake of achieving is often harmful.

Achievement is a powerful source for joy and fulfillment when you are authentic about your desire for success, but can be destructive if you hated getting there.

Be okay with being mediocre at some things, but strive to get better at what you enjoy.

9:30 Actually, this is called the inner critic. It's a perfectly normal experience for most people. 

The keyword being most. And no, being enlightened has nothing to do with the absence of little voice in your head, either. That's called anendophasia; ask me how I know!

Jokes aside, I genuinely have this condition. No little voices in my head. It's astonishingly quiet, and I was very surprised to find out that this wasn't just a figure of speech. Sort of related, my wife actually has aphantasia, which means she can't imagine things / doesn't have a mind's eye. There's also one for being unable to imagine smells, and probably even more.


Oh, and for curious parties, I can imagine sound if I put conscious effort into it (sort of like speaking but inside my head), and I can still imagine songs etc. A complete absence of any inner ear is called anaduralia, which is sort of like a more extreme version of anendophasia. My thoughts are completely wordless, however. It's sort of a flow of ideas and images. I would simply describe it as thinking in thoughts, as weird as that is.

i knew this was gonna be terrible advice, and it did not disappoint..  situationships are about poor communication and poor boundaries.. PERIOD. it's not about getting/having dates.. you can have high standards all you want, and go on dates every damn day, but if you can't say exactly what you want AND walk away when it's not on offer, or walk away when the person doesn't actually follow their word with the matching action, then you won't get a fulfilling relationship... it's not about going on date until you find the perfect person..... no amount of dates will help this. its purely about boundaries and communication. 
example 1: "i am looking for a long term partner" and the person replies "same" but then they don't want to commit to making plans, or match your desire for exclusivity or monogamy, then you walk away because they don't respect your boundaries, and if not.. that's how you end up in a situationship.
example 2: "i am looking for a long term partner" and the person replies "i am not looking for anything serious, mostly just a short term thing" and you DON'T WALK AWAY, that's self abandonment, that's you CHOOSING to compromise you boundaries with a situationship that you think you can charm into being a long term relationship despite them telling you "i am not looking for anything serious, mostly just a short term thing"... so that's you not respecting their boundaries and thinking you can change them.. basically setting yourself up to be tortured by yourself... aka a situationship.

Owning a lot of material things can also
 I.e. property, expensive cars, yachts…can also take away your freedom. You have to maintain them, take insurances…and if you hire staff to take care of them, you still have to take care of your staff. Those are all complexities some people once they get rich, acquire without realizing that it robs them time and freedom.

Time Freedom and Financial Freedom Are Interlocked—but Not Equal.

1. Time Freedom Without Money = Illusion
If you're broke, you're not free. Your time belongs to the job, the bills, the obligations. You’re trading hours for survival, not choice. People romanticize quitting the 9-to-5, but if you have no income stream, all you’ve got is stress disguised as freedom.

2. Financial Freedom Without Time = Golden Cage
You’ve got the cash, but if your schedule is maxed out—meetings, obligations, stress—you’re still a slave. Just richer. Time freedom means autonomy—waking up and choosing what to do, not reacting to what you “have to” do.

You need financial leverage to unlock time freedom. That doesn’t always mean millions—it could be:

1. A business that runs without you.
2. Investments that pay your bills.
3. Skills that let you freelance on your terms.

And from there, time freedom becomes a test of discipline. Most people waste it. They don’t use it to build, they use it to numb.

The need to control every outcome is the mind’s attempt to imitate the perfection that awareness already is. Doing arises naturally when being is honored first. When you rest in the stillness of what you are, action flows from clarity, not fear—from alignment, not compulsion. For… I don’t even know how long, since the first time I watched a video on YouTube, this is the first video that has ever impacted me this much.
What I want to share with you, Ali, is actually something a little different from what you talked about in the video.
Don’t get me wrong — what you said was incredibly impactful.
But here’s the thing… I’m a business owner, and I’ve known for years that I need to start a YouTube channel. The problem is, I’m extremely introverted, so I kept putting it off for as long as I can remember.
By the way, I was one of your early students in YouTube Part-Time.
But when I heard you say that I could just do YouTube for fun… wow. I never thought about it that way before. It felt like the pressure of “doing it for my business” suddenly lifted off my shoulders.
It sounds weird, I know. I’m an introvert who doesn’t even want to be on camera — even though I run a business. But now, if I think of doing YouTube just for fun, it suddenly feels possible.
It’s like… I can do it, but I don’t have to do it.
And that small shift changed everything for me.
Anyway, thank you so much, Ali. I’ll update you 12 months from now on how my channel is doing.
Thank you again!

Law of serotonin - walk headphone free in nature every day
Most important thing is spending time in natural environments. 
The more you spend in a natural environment, the more you will thrive in productivity/etc.
Getting sunlight exposure in the morning increases cortisol (more awake), synchronizes circadian rhythm, sunlight signal tells our brain to make serotonin so we feel happier and energized throughout the day. Even if it's cloudy, you still get the benefit. On a really sunny day, you need 5 mins, on cloudy day, 15 min.
We make 90% of our serotonin in our gut
Eat foods with lots of fiber. Healthier diet = better feel overall.
Better diet = happy gut = happy brain
When eating stuff, make sure you recognize all ingredients. When eating processed food, your gut has to spend energy removing the toxic stuff rather than creating serotonin.
The healthier the diet, the less depressed you are (probably, not scientifically proven or anything)
If the body is breathing very slowly, serotonin levels rise. 
Resonance breathing - breathe 6 times per minute. 
4 seconds in and 6 seconds out 10 times.
Delta sleep. Have a healthy calming wind down period before sleep. Read and resonance breathe before sleep.

6 years ago  I got into shape and started extreme sports and that really slowed down time compared to the decades of sedentary life  before that, but what has really slowed down time in the last couple of years for me has been travelling overseas for 3 months, every 3 months! I don't have the time to get set in my ways or fall into a mindless routine. Also I am learning a new language which might be partially contributing to this. When overseas in public I am always nervous to talk using my new language skills (or lack thereof!) so that part is true.

Now it's August and I can't believe this Christmas, that still is far away, is the one I will stay in country to visit my parents. Even though I am there every 2 years, it seems like years has gone by since last Christmas, thus I get confused, "is this the one we go visit the parents?". 
It's quite an amazingly large change in perception of time! I'm old so this sudden time shift makes me so happy as all I have heard from older people is time speeds up faster and faster, then you die!

I realised this last year during my gap year. I was straight out of highschool, and the first few months I spent waking up super late, playing games the whole day, doom scrolling all the time, and working part time for aorund 12 hours a week. It became incredibly deppressing, and it felt like the first 4 months of the year had passed by quicker than any other time in my life. I realised that I needed to actually experience new and healthy things if I wanted my life to feel slower and have more substance, so I made changes, did new things, played less games, started going to the gym and focused on improving my drawing skills. It worked. the second part of my gap year felt like it went by so much slower, and like I was actually doing good things

I sometimes had tasks to do that I wish I could delegate to someone else because they seemed overwhelming, would just drain my energy and take lots of time to do. But those tasks were an opportunity to think about how they could be done smarter and more efficient. To find a more systematic way. At the end doing these tasks helped me grow, and invent new techniques. It's a training for your brain, that you cannot get if you just do the things that you enjoy and that come easy to you.

Read indistractable and Digital Minimalism

Also screens are not the issue, but what’s on them. Yeah ok too much screen time does put too much strain on your eyes and lead to headaches etc, but the things we blame on screens is actually due to what sort of stuff we are consuming, namely a lot of mindless, short content, playing havoc with our attention. If someone spent 18 hours of a day reading a book on their iPad, their eyes would probably feel the strain and we’d probably recommend they read on paper or e-ink, but they may not feel like they’ve wasted their day, depending on the book/other commitments they’re neglecting. So we need to build systems that help us detach from various fast paced streams of information, such as social media or the news

6 hours and 40 minutes? I don’t buy that. Ok yeah let’s not include watching TV on an actual TV let’s say. I’d say a significant majority of people are looking at a desktop or laptop or tablet screen for much of the working day (let’s say 6-8 hours). That’s 6 hours 40 minutes even before using screens outside work is taken into account. Most people use YouTube, Instagram and Tiktok, each I’d say for close to an hour. So we’re up to about 9-11 hours. Plus then texting and other web browsing and I’d reckon we’re looking at more like 11-13 hours. People are on screens during every hour they’re not asleep. Most people sleep about 6-8 hours. So for 16-18 hours of the day people are looking at screens in those hours. By these very rough calculations there are 5 hours without screens. That’s about 80% of the whole day spent on screens. I just don’t know where these stats come from. Anyone else think they’re massively undercooked?

Thanks for watching! What did you learn about dopamine? And if you're interested, you can sign up to my free 7 day focus crash course here: https://go.aliabdaal.com/dopvid

Notes:
- People are experiencing more anxiety and depression due to the endless levels of dopamine that we get
- Things that don't release a lot of dopamine (reading, watching a slow documentary, taking a walk in the park, being with friends) don't make us feel good anymore
- Dopamine detox: Stop doing too much of what gives you the bad dopamine (scrolling, tv, video games, gambling, sugary foods). Learn to enjoy the simple pleasures in life.

But do the big corporations offer support to the drainers to actually help them become energizers? In my experience, no. 

I worked for a huge insurance company for 13 years and during COVID lockdown they acted like nothing changed (since I worked from home). WFH did not exempt me from the effects of that time, but they expected business as usual. 

I was always a high performer, but after that it steadily declined and they fired me. If I were a manager, I’d wonder why an employee performs the way they do and try to address it in a meaningful way before giving someone the boot— especially if they used to perform well. 

Telling someone who is struggling to “just do better” doesn’t work, just as telling someone who drains others to “just become an energizer” might not have the wanted effect. 

How can we help these people? I know some of it is them wanting to help themselves, but also not everyone has the same level of self-awareness. I would love to hear possible solutions to issues in the workplace like this.

Thanks for all the support over the years gang ❤You can check out all 20 life lessons from my 20s here! https://go.aliabdaal.com/lessons30vid

I love that comment about focusing on the “process” and not the “outcome!” Mic drop. I absolutely agree.

Because how often do we as a society focus on the outcome? 100% of the time. The whole reason we work our tails off for 4 years at university is to walk across that stage with the diploma in hand because of what that paper will allow us to do. We go to work for a whole two weeks or a whole month so that in the end we have that paycheck in hand. Because that paycheck means we can trade it in for what we want or need. 

But how happier a life we might lead if we focused on enjoying the life experience of working with people from different walks of life or at university not dreaming about graduation day when you can finally leave campus, but rather in recognizing you’ve learned to love learning (which I will honestly say is good for the growth of our spirit). Focusing on moments with roommates hanging out around the sofa watching a movie or baking a dessert in the oven, pranking the men’s apartment across the parking lot by sticking Oreos to their front living room window and so on.
Life sure passes us by fast. It’s now that I am a parent that I look back on all those good times at university and wonder why I didn’t take more photos of the moments and not worry so much about the little things. 

Now I am learning to view parenthood not as “hard and lots of work” and many sleepless nights (especially in the beginning), but rather focusing on the fact that never again will my babies be as little as they are, now is the time to train them in the way they should go. And while I’m at it take a few photos of today, no matter the mess in the background. :)

I’m nowhere near your level, but I’ve been selling courses and ebooks online for a few years in the guitar-lessons niche. For context, I’ve built around 73k followers on Facebook, 14k across Instagram/TikTok (mostly faceless content), 2.2k on YouTube and a 2k email list… and honestly, I’ve made *pittance* from digital products.

I’m now in the process of pivoting into a less saturated niche “Tenor banjo”, and based on my experience so far, a couple of things might help others:

1. Don’t rely on faceless content — even if gurus push it. I spent over a year doing nothing but faceless videos, and they made me nothing. Showing your face and building a real connection matters more than people admit.

2. Look for blue-ocean opportunities. Some niches are completely crowded (the guitar niche). Sometimes the best move is to find a parallel niche or an underserved angle where you can actually stand out.

Hopefully that helps someone who’s on the same journey. Thanks again for the great video.

I had a project to scan and preserve the yearbooks from my husband's high school.  I back-planned from the last day of the summer until I got to the first yearbook.  There were 2 volumes per day, 5 days a week, excluding our vacation weeks.  My daughter and I shared the work (odds and evens); when we finished one, we would work on the next one because the newer volumes had more pages.  We were 80 pages from finishing the project before my daughter had to go back to school.  By doing this, I could say 1985 will be ready by Tuesday because otherwise, it would back up all the others.  So now I have to divide all my projects into days and just do it.

So we did this one test in PE in highschool where we would do 3 rounds of exercises to see in which round we could do the most sets of those exercises...the results were really interesting because it showed us how our specific bodies work and how we could use it to our advantage. I did the most in the third round which means I get more energized the more I do physically... I'm guessing you are the same as me. So even now, 10 years after that test in highschool I still think about it and it's so helpful to know how my body works. Even few months ago it was proven to be true. I had one job but it wasn't enough for me (ambition wise) so I went to get 2 more jobs and I had enough energy for all of them. But when I was unemployed I literally had no energy to even go to the bathroom or cook for myself let alone go to a job interview. So for me I always need to keep myself at least a little busy so I have energy to do more things if I want to, I can never let myself do nothing for even a day or I will fall into a hole of lazyness I won't be able to get out of easily.
Taking ownership it is! 💡

Worked in IT operations for years. Background is from development, though. So I automated and scripted my work as much as possible.

Usually colleagues had 1-3 services they had to maintain, friend of mine had about a dozen. Automation allowed me to operate about 40 services with almost no active work on them. Only had to look after bugs, tickets, etc and could spend my time doing what I liked: scripting, creating graphs from logs, etc.

After almost ten years I left the company, heading out into the world where I now work as a freelancer in automation.

I absolutely love this!! A couple of years ago I started mapping out my yearly goals, then set quarterly, monthly, weekly and even daily goals. To help keep me on track I map out my whole year on an Excel spreadsheet from 5am to 10pm, 7 days a week, everything is planned. I review once a week, then have monthly and quarterly reviews. For a lot of people, it’s probably overkill, but it works for me and keeps me on track. I refer to my excel sheet as my ‘best case plan’ that way I don’t get too overwhelmed when things go off track, which they do!!

Feeling good leads to success

                                                         ~ali abdaal

Maintaining a consistent state of well-being is a multifaceted endeavor that involves nurturing both your mental and physical health. Cultivating a positive mindset is crucial; challenge negative thoughts and focus on optimistic perspectives. Regularly practicing gratitude—acknowledging and appreciating the positive aspects of your life—can contribute significantly to your overall mood.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment is essential. Whether it's pursuing hobbies, spending time with loved ones, or simply taking a stroll in nature, these activities can positively impact your emotional state. Additionally, setting and achieving realistic goals provides a sense of accomplishment, boosting self-esteem.

A cornerstone of feeling good is maintaining a healthy lifestyle. This includes regular exercise, a balanced diet, sufficient sleep, and stress management. Physical well-being is closely linked to mental health, and taking care of your body positively influences your mood and energy levels.

Moreover, fostering strong social connections is crucial for emotional well-being. Surround yourself with supportive friends and family, and prioritize meaningful relationships. Sharing experiences and emotions with others can provide comfort and a sense of belonging.

Ultimately, feeling good always is an ongoing process that requires self-awareness and intentional efforts. It's about creating a balanced and positive lifestyle that aligns with your values and promotes both physical and mental well-being.

I feel like most of these points work in a very abstract perfect scenario and not in real life. People are unique, their paths are unique and their needs can be different at different points. E.g. you might prioritize financial stability at one point then growth, meeting new people etc. and these are constantly changing. So don't try to find perfect career, just find what you are curious about in your current one, see where this leads you.

This video discusses seven actionable tips from Matthew Dicks' book "Someday is Today" to help you achieve more of what you want in life:
 * The Parking Lot Practice: True productivity doesn't require a perfect environment. You can make progress on your goals even in imperfect settings and short bursts of time [01:44], [02:24].
 * The Minute Mindset: Utilize small pockets of time, even just a few minutes, to make progress on your tasks instead of waiting for large blocks of time [03:04], [04:11].
 * The Lily Pad Method: When working on a big project, don't feel like you have to do things in a strict sequence. Jump between different tasks or aspects of the project depending on your mood and motivation [06:29], [07:23].
 * The Horizon Habit: Instead of setting rigid, specific goals that might be outside your control, set general, directional "horizon goals" that allow for flexibility in how you achieve your aspirations [09:02], [09:20].
 * The Piano Precedent: While planning is helpful, be prepared for unexpected events that might disrupt your plans. Life rarely follows a perfectly linear path [10:22], [11:15].
 * The 100-Year Old Plan: When facing a decision, imagine what your 100-year-old self would advise you to do. This helps prioritize long-term values over short-term urgencies [11:35], [11:59].
 * The Purposeful Approach: Productivity isn't just about work or business; it's about efficiently doing the things that allow you to spend more time on what truly matters to you, including "soft goals" that bring you meaning and fulfillment [13:03], [13:41].

The assumption within this that you will get instant feedback on what you publish is not what happens in reality. You need people to see and read your stuff before you can get feedback. No one has an audience when they start out. You need an audience to get feedback. And you need feedback to get an audience. In other words, it’s a catch 22.

Your teacher was right when they said, "Not everyone can become a writer." However, they likely did not explain why they made that statement. There are countless reasons why everyone cannot become a writer. You asked, "Then why are we all here?" Well, you were there to gain knowledge and develop comprehension skills in several subjects—not just writing—in pursuit of your goals. Not everyone's goal is to become a writer. Moreover, you were also in school because the law (truancy policies) required it; otherwise, your parents could face a judge explaining why you were not attending. 

You were there to learn how to write, among other subjects, but not necessarily to "become a writer." If everyone could become a writer, why do so many people struggle with it? I have heard people say they used tools from videos, but nothing worked. Additionally, I’ve read comments from people on YouTube who followed advice from creators, only to have their writings rejected. 

Let me share a couple of abridged examples from my experience. My teachers always complimented my writing. As a child and later a teenager, those compliments meant little to me because, in my naïve and dismissive mind, "everyone writes." I would shrug it off and move on. Then came the SAT, where I scored very high, nearly reaching the maximum score, with my writing section achieving the top score. In college, my professors often praised my writing, inviting me to join the college newspaper and sit on editorial panels. Despite receiving invitations to join various organizations, including the International Honor Society, I still didn’t realize the significance of my writing ability. 

So, what didn’t I get? Keep reading. I became a teacher and passed the writing portion of the teacher certification exam with a perfect score. Later, I was assigned to teach student teachers who had failed the writing portion of the exam. After working with me, they all passed. Yet, it wasn’t until graduate school that I truly began to understand my gift. I graduated with double majors and the only 4.0 GPA in my program—still unaware that graduate school revolves heavily around writing and being published. After turning in my final writing assignment, research study, and manual, my professor wrote her farewell as my professor and referred to me as Author Gail Becker. 

If it had not been for that professor, I would not have become a writer, nor would I be teaching my students and elderly clients how to write their memoirs. 

It took me years to realize I had both the gift and talent for writing. Despite all the compliments I received, I never considered becoming a writer because it wasn’t one of my three original goals: acting, modeling, or teaching. While I achieved those goals, I eventually embraced writing. 

So, while some may have a natural propensity for writing, not everyone can or will become a writer. Always remember: if everyone could, then everyone would.

Well, I travelled as much as I could in my 20's, started therapy plus personal development as much as I could, laughed as much as I could, read everything coming my way as much as I could (articles, books, blog posts, comments on socials etc..) plus I got into my dream line of job / sector from my first professional grown up contract I'll say. I knew what I wanted to do from the age of 13. Now, I'm 45 and I currently operate a career change that sometimes makes me feel that I lost my North Star ✨ but I do it anyway (even imperfectly...)I also know deep inside that it is the right thing to do, it's just that I can't see or experience the things that would make me feel super self-confident, from where I stand right now. I haven't read the book 📚 yet but by experience I'll say that achieving dreams, not only goals, developing a strong sense of self, of humour as well as personal values that will nurture your sense of humanity and empathy, plus making amazing memories (travels, healthy and diverse social life, deep intercultural conversation, intellectual curiosity, speaking more than 1 language etc.
plus I've never been drunk or tried any kind of drug) early in your adult life make very much of a difference down the road 🛣️🛣️🛣️ I feel the benefit of it every single day. It changes your perspective on happiness, personal development and so much more... A lot of things that the majority of people think are impossible to achieve (happiness, self-actualisation....) are actually very achievable. Happiness at the bottom line relies on your hormonal system so, there is no way it couldn't be achievable.... Almost everything in life is a matter of perspective that allows the experiences, the experiences allow the beliefs, the beliefs allow systematic cognitive behaviours plus also personal values etc. etc..... Well, you know what I mean. Whenever you start understanding a bit how things work, then Life becomes easier and easier... I'd add that curing, healing that inherited systematic sense of contradiction is critical. I've seen people along the way doing and achieving an astonishing amount of right things (healthy lifestyle, yoga, volunteering, financial freedom, beauty etc.) BUT behind all possible closed doors they would contradict those things systematically because of nasty and hidden personal values (but still very real)and the belief systems they relie on, therefore that...systematically diminished their sense of humanity.... I can tell you without a doubt that they will never be happy nor self-actualized. FACT. I've learnt about contradiction in Philosophy classes back in highschool, my prof always said you should never contradict yourself in any possible way (like not only verbally but also in your values, behaviour....) and it sticks magnetically with me. It's been 2 decades now and I can see how much he was right about that. I'm not out of the woods yet 😂😂 and I struggled with a few things in Life, money is one of them. I still have work to do and things to figure out but I'm close enough to believe that there is a way and a right way to believe and do things if you want to live the human experience to its fullest... My point is..I'll definitely read this book 📖😁😁😁😁

I was deep into offshore strategies, trusts, and second passports when someone casually mentioned The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan. They said, “This will tie it all together.” It did. That book made me realize I wasn’t thinking big enough- or quiet enough. It’s the kind of read that makes you want to erase your digital footprint and start over.

I read The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan after someone in a private group called it “a map for the invisible empire.” That’s exactly what it felt like. The book doesn’t push you toward more income- it peels back layers of ownership, liability, and silence. Since reading it, I’ve moved everything differently. I play a different game now.

I was in a room with three people who’d each exited with over $50M. One of them asked, “Have you read The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan yet?” Everyone else nodded. I didn’t even know what it was. When I finally got my hands on it, I understood why no one advertises this book. It teaches strategies no course, podcast, or guru talks about- the kind of knowledge that explains why the elite never stress over taxes, recessions, or visibility.

When I first started making money, I thought lawyers and accountants had the answers. Then I met someone worth 8 figures who told me his whole strategy came from The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan. After reading it, I understood why he never used his name, never kept anything in one country, and never talked publicly about anything. The book isn’t a shortcut. It’s a cipher for understanding how money becomes power- not income.

A friend of mine renounced his citizenship and now lives on a yacht with no traceable income, no debt, and no liabilities. I asked him what started that journey and he said, “A book. The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan.” He was right. That book flipped everything I knew upside down. It’s not for beginners. It’s for people who are done playing the game by the rules they were handed.

I met a guy in Lisbon who used to be a high-level tax strategist. Said he left the system not because it was corrupt- but because it was too transparent. He told me to read The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan. That book didn’t tell me how to make more money- it showed me how the truly wealthy become invisible. It explains the game behind the game. I haven’t looked at a single income stream the same since.

A girl I dated briefly told me her father never had a job, but owned properties under shell companies all over the world. When I asked her how he learned that, she said, “He reads things most people never find. Like The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan.” I tracked it down. It’s not your average finance book. It’s like a manual for becoming untraceable- not because you’re hiding, but because you’re free.

A friend of mine in Dubai told me something I’ll never forget: “If people can find you, they can take from you.” Then he sent me The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan and said, “Read this before you make another move.” It didn’t tell me how to make more- it showed me how to vanish from the balance sheets that matter. Since then, I’ve owned less and controlled more.

The sunk loss fallacy explains the delusional belief to which we are all susceptible in the course of our life’s journey, and in all undertakings - whether they be born of personal desire or external impetus by which we become pressured to act. Enthralled by the fallacy, we eschew the understanding of our present reality, and future prospects, all in favour of the more base desire to prove ourselves right or to validate the sacrifice we have made for an end, an end that is by this point no longer possible. Born of hopes, the end becomes hopelessness when aspired towards.

The best and cheap way to brew good aromatic coffee is the old Singapore coffeeshop way. 

All you need is a big pot, 
- put a big cloth coffee bag into the pot, 
- add the desired coffee grounds into the bag, 
- pour hot water into the ground coffee, 
- let the coffee seep for 5 minutes,
- serve it with milk or sugar. 

If you like it thinner then add more water into the brewed coffee. Enjoy. :D

I switched to KindleScribe over 9 months now from my Kindle Oasis. I bought it mainly for the big screen and to read pdfs. It makes reading feel more like reading from a real book. The device does not feel heavy and I use it without a cover (stored in a pouch) as I like to feel it. It is thin and  has premium feel to it and is not too hard on the hands. E-book pages with charts, graphs and inserts now feel more like real book pages. 

Pdfs are easy to read as the screen is bigger. Yet, zooming to read small text is not convenient. If there is small text and you need to zoom, then I wouldn't read it. If the it has large text and more images like PowerPoint presentations, then it is great to read. Magazines with heavy graphics take a second or two to load, but the issue is font size. 

The best part is you could write anywhere on the e-books and pdfs like you would scribble on real books. You can also access all your notes, highlights and underlines in one place. Battery lasts forever, and the writing experience is top notch. I would definitely recommend upgrading to KindleScribe from other Kindle devices. I am using the 2022 version and don't see a need to upgrade to the latest version as the same software updates and features are available on both devices.

The scribe is the smallest I can go without reading glasses, thanks to age and the wonderful presbyopia.  So increase the font size on a regular kindle or the paperwhite, would probably look like flash cards, hardly useful.  So having at least a 10.3 or even a 13.3 means I can sit back comfortably, increase the font size, and read without any glasses.  But yes, for the mobile reading, I have the BOOX Palma 6.13" for the ultimate in traveling ebook readers, which has Android, and can store 128GB onboard, and I have a 1TB MicroSD card external slot in it, for 1128GB of storage.  It can hold movies, audiobooks, hundreds of MP3s, complete ebook epub and PDF archives, etc.  All the fun you can ever imagine, all in the palm (Palma) of your hands.  That's true portability and power!  And since it has the full Google Play store, it means that I can have my library book apps, Kobo, and Kindle apps all on it.

I once had dinner with a man who used to run a multi-billion dollar hedge fund. No interviews, no social media, no Wikipedia page. Just connections. I asked him how the wealthy stay wealthy even during recessions. He leaned in and said, “They don’t save. They print. Quietly.” Then he handed me a worn copy of How the Elite Print Their Wealth. “Read this,” he said. “Then look at your bank the way they look at you.” I didn’t sleep that night. What that book laid out wasn’t theory- it was a reality I’d been trained not to see.

I found a copy of How the Elite Print Their Wealth in my business partner’s drawer. No bookmarks, no highlights- just notes scribbled on the inside cover like it was a cipher. When I asked about it, he said, “That book is why I never worry about taxes, recessions, or audits.” I thought he was exaggerating. He wasn’t. The book broke down how real wealth moves in silence- through trusts, paper losses, and controlled chaos. I realized I’d been building a business. He’d been building a fortress.

Halfway through How the Elite Print Their Wealth, I realized something: this wasn’t written for people like me. It was written by someone who walked the halls of private equity firms, trust law offices, and offshore banking conferences- and decided to blow the whistle. That’s what it feels like. A quiet whistleblow. It doesn’t just explain wealth… it unlocks the operating system behind it. If this book ever goes viral, I wouldn’t be surprised if it quietly disappears.

I used to walk around angry, thinking the system was broken, rigged, unfair. But after reading How the Elite Print Their Wealth, I realized- the system works exactly as designed. I just wasn’t invited to understand it. That book showed me how wealth is quietly created through legal structures, debt, and time- not labor. It was like someone turned on the lights in a room I didn’t know I was in. Nothing about how I see money, taxes, or “income” has been the same since.

I was reviewing a partnership agreement for a real estate deal and something about the structure felt off- like the profits were invisible but the control was absolute. My attorney said, “This is family office-level structuring.” I didn’t even know what that meant until I read How the Elite Print Their Wealth. Suddenly that contract made sense. It wasn’t about owning- it was about positioning. I realized the rich don’t win by being on the front lines. They win by being above the battlefield entirely.

I was on a long-haul flight from Zürich next to an older guy who didn’t talk until the final hour. We started chatting about wealth, and I mentioned how I felt like I was always “catching up.” He said, “You’re trying to earn wealth. The elite print it.” Then he gave me a title: How the Elite Print Their Wealth. That single sentence, and that book, made me rethink everything: income, structure, ownership, exposure. Now I don’t hustle harder. I just design smarter. The game didn’t change- I did.

I’ve read a lot of business books. Some inspire. Some educate. But How the Elite Print Their Wealth? It rewired me. It didn’t just teach me new tactics- it made me realize I was using the wrong operating system. Since reading it, I’ve set up a holding company, shifted how I pay myself, and legally cut my tax exposure in half. I don’t “grind” anymore. I architect. Total life pivot- and it started with a single book I randomly saw mentioned in a comment section.

About your spirit coming alive when you choose the career that you genuinely enjoy pursuing: for example, if you're an MD but also enjoy coding or creative writing as a hobby, you might find yourself thinking, 'I’m actually looking forward to my creative writing more than talking to patients.' However, the reverse isn’t as simple. If you're a coder wondering, 'Would I enjoy medicine more?' it’s incredibly hard to test that curiosity. Reading about medicine, shadowing doctors, or even studying medical theory can’t fully replicate the experience. It’s only during hospital rotations that you might get a real sense of what it’s like—but by then, you’ve already committed so much time and effort. So, that question lingers, and there’s no easy way to satisfy that curiosity. You may be a coder and second-guess your carrer choice, thinking about medicine instead, but you cannot obtain enough input to help you assess that you should shift the carrer path, because how can you know after potential six years you would like medicine?

I tried verifying his claim saying that "97% of night shift workers DO NOT adapt to the demands of working at night", but 4 sources said that it's not entirely acurrate to say that.

Opus 4.1 Thinking with Search says:
Night shift workers do partially adapt to working at night, but research shows this adaptation is typically incomplete and comes with significant challenges.
Partial Adaptation Occurs
The human body can shift its circadian rhythms to some degree when exposed to consistent night work schedules. Workers who maintain the same night schedule for weeks or months show measurable changes in their melatonin production timing, core body temperature rhythms, and alertness patterns. Performance and alertness during night hours generally improve after several consecutive night shifts.
Why Complete Adaptation Rarely Happens
Several factors prevent full adaptation to night work:
Biological constraints: Our circadian system evolved to align with natural light-dark cycles. Even with artificial light manipulation, the body's master clock in the brain strongly resists complete inversion of its natural rhythm.
Social and environmental conflicts: Most night workers revert to daytime schedules on days off to participate in family and social activities. This constant switching between schedules prevents stable adaptation. Daylight exposure during commutes home and light leaking into bedrooms during daytime sleep further disrupts adjustment.
Individual variation: Some people adapt better than others due to genetic differences in circadian clock genes. "Night owls" typically fare better than "morning larks" on night shifts, but even they rarely achieve complete adaptation.
Health Consequences Persist
Studies consistently show that even experienced night shift workers who feel they've adapted still experience higher rates of cardiovascular disease, metabolic disorders, digestive issues, and mood disturbances compared to day workers. Cognitive performance, particularly for complex tasks requiring sustained attention, often remains impaired during night hours even after years of night work.
The evidence suggests that while humans can partially adjust to night work, our bodies never fully overcome the fundamental misalignment between our internal biological clock and working against the natural light-dark cycle.

Grok 3 says:
The idea that night shift workers don't adapt to working at night isn't entirely accurate, but there's a kernel of truth to it. Humans are biologically wired for diurnal activity—our circadian rhythms, driven by the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the brain, naturally align with a 24-hour cycle of daylight and darkness. This means that for most people, working at night goes against their internal clock, making adaptation challenging.
That said, adaptation is possible to varying degrees. Some night shift workers can partially adjust their circadian rhythms through consistent schedules, controlled light exposure (e.g., avoiding blue light during "daytime" sleep hours and using bright light during work hours), and other behavioral strategies. However, complete adaptation is rare. Studies, like those from the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), show that even long-term night workers often experience "circadian misalignment," leading to issues like sleep deprivation, fatigue, and increased risk of health problems such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes.
On the flip side, individual differences play a huge role. Some people—often called "night owls" due to genetic predispositions (e.g., variations in the PER3 gene)—are naturally more suited to late hours and may adapt better than early birds forced into night shifts. Age also matters; younger workers tend to adjust more easily than older ones due to greater flexibility in sleep patterns.
So, while many night shift workers struggle to fully adapt, it's not a universal rule. The human body is stubborn about its daylight preferences, but with the right strategies or inherent traits, some can make it work—though often at a cost to long-term health if not managed carefully. If you're curious about specific coping mechanisms or health data, I can dig deeper into those!

AI Overview in Google Search says:

The claim that 97% of night shift workers don't adapt is a specific statistic that is not supported by available research. While it's difficult to fully adapt to night shifts because they go against our innate circadian rhythms, studies show that many workers struggle with sleep quality and experience various health issues. Instead of a fixed percentage, the research indicates that circadian disruption is a common challenge, leading to difficulties in sleep, increased health risks, and negative impacts on well-being. 
Why Adapting Is Difficult
Physiological Clocks: The human body is naturally wired to be awake during the day and sleep at night, driven by light-dark cycles. 
Circadian Rhythm Resistance: The central clock in the body is resistant to adapting to a day-oriented schedule to a night-oriented one. This means that even with consistent night shifts, the body struggles to fully realign its sleep-wake cycle. 
Quality vs. Quantity: Workers may get enough sleep in terms of hours, but the quality of that sleep is often poor, leading to ongoing fatigue. 
Consequences of Poor Adaptation
Health Issues: Shift work can increase the risk of metabolic disorders, cardiovascular disease, and some cancers. 
Mental Health: Social isolation and other factors can contribute to concerns for mental health among shift workers. 
Performance: Difficulties with sleep and wakefulness lead to impaired performance and increased risks of accidents. 
What Helps
Sleep Environment: Using blackout curtains, eye masks, and earplugs to block out light and noise can help improve daytime sleep quality. 
Consistency: While not a perfect solution, trying to maintain a consistent sleep schedule can be beneficial. 
Supplements and Aids: Melatonin supplements and sleep aids may provide temporary relief for some individuals. 



AI Mode from Google says:
The figure that 97% of night shift workers don't adapt is not substantiated by medical research and may come from anecdotal claims found on forums like Reddit. Scientific studies show that most people have difficulty fully adapting to night work, but the inability to adapt is not as universal as 97% suggests. 
Medical research on shift work points to the following issues, which confirm that full adaptation is not a common experience: 
Circadian misalignment: The body's internal clock is very resistant to shifting to a nocturnal schedule, even for permanent night workers. For those who switch to a day schedule on their days off, the body's rhythms are in a state of constant "roller-coaster swings".
Persistent health risks: Working against the natural circadian rhythm increases the risk of numerous health problems, including cardiovascular disease, diabetes, obesity, and gastrointestinal disorders.
Sleep disruption: The most significant challenge is sleep disturbance. Night workers experience poor-quality, fragmented, and insufficient sleep, which leads to chronic sleep deprivation and fatigue.
Varied individual tolerance: The ability to cope with shift work varies from person to person. Some individuals may have a genetic predisposition that makes them more sensitive to sleep loss and circadian disruption. One estimate suggests that about 20% of workers who attempt shift work are unable to tolerate it. 
In summary, while the 97% figure is an exaggeration, it is a fact that the vast majority of night shift workers struggle with the health and sleep demands of their schedule. The challenges are so significant that many never fully adjust, even if they manage to continue working the shift.

My opinions:

Kindle Basic (what I use):
9.8/10

Pros:
Very affordable Kindle.
Lightweight Kindle.
Easy to balance in your hands.
Smooth page turns.
You can use dark mode to filter out blue light.

Cons:
Lacks warm light.
A smaller screen.
Not waterproof.
Limited storage.

Kindle Paperwhite (what I also use):
8/10

Pros:
The battery life lasts weeks.
The screen has a warm light.
The screen has a glare free, e ink display.
Bigger screen.
Waterproof.
Page turns are faster.
Ecosystem.

Cons:
Expensive Kindle.
The library browsing can lag.
Text annotation can be more difficult.

Kindle Paperwhite Signature:
7.5/10

Pros:
The front light automatically adjusts to your environment.
Wireless charging.
32GB of storage.
Faster processing.

Cons:
Higher price.
The storage is technically unnecessary.
Display can lag.

Kindle Oasis:
4.5/10

Pros:
Comfortable grip.
Adjustable warm light.
High quality display.
Waterproof.
Automatic page orientation.

Cons:
micro-USB port.
Very expensive.
Battery life is shorter.
Value proposition.

Kindle Scribe:
4/10

Pros:
Large screen, resulting in an excellent reading experience.
Great handwriting experience.
Solid battery life.
Good for occasional note taking.
Useful for marking up documents.

Cons:
Expensive.
Limited notebook software.
Difficult text annotation.
Poor AI features.
Frustrating file support.
Heavy.
Closed ecosystem.

Kindle Colorsoft:
5/10

Pros:
Colour display.
Waterproof.
Wireless charging.
Adjustable front light.
The Signature Edition has an auto-adjust light.

Cons:
Very expensive.
Battery life is very minimal.
Text clarity is less sharp.
The colours are muted.
No stylus support.
Less storage.

I switched to KindleScribe over 9 months now from my Kindle Oasis. I bought it mainly for the big screen and to read pdfs. It makes reading feel more like reading from a real book. The device does not feel heavy and I use it without a cover (stored in a pouch) as I like to feel it. It is thin and  has premium feel to it and is not too hard on the hands. E-book pages with charts, graphs and inserts now feel more like real book pages. 

Pdfs are easy to read as the screen is bigger. Yet, zooming to read small text is not convenient. If there is small text and you need to zoom, then I wouldn't read it. If the it has large text and more images like PowerPoint presentations, then it is great to read. Magazines with heavy graphics take a second or two to load, but the issue is font size. 

The best part is you could write anywhere on the e-books and pdfs like you would scribble on real books. You can also access all your notes, highlights and underlines in one place. Battery lasts forever, and the writing experience is top notch. I would definitely recommend upgrading to KindleScribe from other Kindle devices. I am using the 2022 version and don't see a need to upgrade to the latest version as the same software updates and features are available on both devices.

An important factor for me is the idea of utilising current financial stability to own fully a home in the future, which if - let’s say - can be repaid in 10/15y time, can alleviate a lot of financial pressure coming from constantly renting. Investing in the stock market might return ~7% per year, but in 10 years time you’ll just have more money in your hands; for some maybe not even enough to buy a home at the time. Also owing your home for me can cultivate further psychological stability; you have freedom to create a home as you like it. Plus, if the value of the property goes up, you can sell it and have a decent ROI. Constantly renting has been ok for me but has been making feel a) that I help repay someone else’s mortgage, b) that I don’t have the independence and sense of home I’d like.

Compromised senses - sight, hearing, balance etc - cause disorientation, corrected by enhancing the remaining competent senses.  It's a function, not a flaw.  Blind people can develop enhanced hearing and spatial memory.  Deaf people become hyper-sensitive to facial expression and body-language.  Emotionally 'interrupted' people adapt also.  As Gabor Maté describes, trauma is a self-preserving behaviour that made sense eat the time of actual challenge (abuse or neglect), but has out-lived it's usefulness and, in fact, is now a burden.  It is interesting that, if my father burst my eardrums and deafened me after smacking me in the side of the head, when I was a child, I would be treated as an actual casualty, with sympathetic treatment, accommodation and rights as befits a 'disabled' person.  However, if my father only broke my mind with his hands, the resulting dysfunction would be regarded as a burden on humanity, I would be isolated as 'difficult' or 'complex' if I didn't seek therapy or I would be shunned as weak and compromised, if I DID seek therapy.  However, broken minds need drugs, healthcare, entertainment, prisons, excessive food and drink, materialism, serial marriages etc; i.e. misery is a boundless and fruitful market.

Experience is the best teacher. But why wait to learn from your own experience while you can pick the lessons from other people’s experiences? Well, if you are like me, then you know making money is awesome. Spending it is way gratifying. However, with poor management, your hard-earned money can be flushed down the drain with only one snap of a finger. After intensive research, I discovered that money is a game of numbers, and if calculated well, you get to enjoy its benefits. Money can either be a slave or a master. A rule of thumb: If you bleed money more that you make, then you are a slave to money. However, if you make more money than you spend, then money becomes your slave. 

“What is done cannot be undone, but at least one can keep it from happening again.”-Anne Frank. Money management entails more than just making money to yield the highest interest. It also involves budgeting, saving, investing, spending, and tending to your debts. Spending without planning causes financial stress and eventually leads to depression. Here is my top ten list of common money mistakes.

1. Not budgeting
2. Disregard towards savings 
3. Not having insurance
4. Impulse buying
5. Bad Loans
6. Spending more than you earn
7. Not setting financial goals
8. Not having an emergency fund
9. Not taking free time to make extra money
10. Not discussing finances with your partner

Read more on common money mistakes here: 
https://elidayjuma.com/common-money-mistakes-to-avoid/

Never to put all my eggs in one basket. Now, I try to split mine between Stocks and Real Estate such that if one is affected, I would not be too affected and that has paid off as I made my first million earlier this year through this method (got the help of a pro though). 興味深い内容の動画ありがとうございました。以下に簡単にまとめさせていただきました。


**オンラインで収益を得るための7つの副業アイデア**

この動画では、オンラインで始められる7つの副業アイデアが紹介されています。最初のアイデアは「YouTuber向けの動画編集」で、編集スキルは短期間で習得可能で、FiverrやUpworkで仕事を探せます。また、好きなYouTuberの動画を編集し実績を示すことで、仕事を得る可能性が高まります。他にも、「オンライン家庭教師」では、自分のスキルや知識を活かして、生徒に教えることができます。特に語学レッスンや大学入試指導が需要があります。

さらに、「ウェブデザイナー」では、簡単なツールを使用してウェブサイトを作成し、特定の業界に特化することで顧客を獲得可能。「ソーシャルメディアコンサルタント」は、SNSの知識を活かし、企業のアカウント運用を支援します。また、「Notionコンサルタント」では、企業の業務フローを効率化するサービスを提供できます。加えて、「ライター業」では、ブログ記事やSEO対策の記事執筆で収益を得られます。

最後に、「有料ニュースレターの運営」も有望なアイデアとして挙げられています。どの副業もスキルと努力が必要ですが、ターゲットを適切に絞ることで成功の可能性が広がります。

Ali! Thanks for hosting me on the channel. I literally flew halfway across the world for this collaboration and it was totally worth it. 

Now that the video is live, I want to provide some more color about why people should get started as online writers, regardless of whether they want to eventually start a blog or a YouTube channel. 

1. Attract friends and business partners: It's hard to meet people as passionate about learning as you are. But when you publish your ideas, you attract people who think like you. The more niche the topic, the easier it is to attract people on your intellectual wavelength.

2. Writing helps you understand yourself. All of us have unprocessed feelings and emotions. Writing is the best way to identify what's making you uncomfortable. By writing, you gain clarity in your life. The increased clarity you receive reduces stress and anxiety in your life.

3. Writing accelerates your learning: If you want to understand a topic better, start teaching it. The act of putting ideas into your own words tattoos them into your mind. As James Clear once said: "If you think you can learn a lot by reading a book, try writing one."

4. Writing makes you more observant: Whenever you write something, new parts of the world come alive. Every experience, every conversation, and everything you read becomes a potential future sentence. That's why writing regularly wakes you up and makes your mind come alive.

5. Writing establishes expertise: Excellent essays attract excellent people. If you write well about a topic, the world's experts will reach out to you. Since writing is a record of your best ideas, your essays will double as a resume that demonstrates your intellectual rigor.

6. Writing will accelerate your career: Good writers are clear thinkers and clear thinkers are rewarded at work. By writing, you can gain outsized influence in your company and establish yourself as an industry expert, which will attract opportunities.

7. Writing attracts opportunities: Every article you publish is like a serendipity vehicle. High-level people who resonate with your ideas will reach out to you with career opportunities you couldn't have imagined. Thus, writing maximizes your surface area of exposure to luck.

8. Writing improves your thinking: Mathematicians put their ideas on the whiteboard because writing out your ideas lets you tackle harder problems. Writing is the same. By putting ideas onto the page, you can transcend the limits of scattered thinking and explore ideas deeply.

9. Writing online forces you to think better: Thinking in public raises your standard for quality. When I was a kid, our house was always cleanest when guests would come over. The same is true for writing. You think better when you know you're going to be seen and critiqued.

Finally, I think it's worth answering one more question: Why is now the time to write?

It's never been easier for average people to share their ideas. If you write well, your ideas will find their way to some of the smartest and most successful people in the world. As your reputation grows, so will the opportunities available to you.

Writing regularly is one of the best habits you can build.

I once had dinner with a man who used to run a multi-billion dollar hedge fund. No interviews, no social media, no Wikipedia page. Just connections. I asked him how the wealthy stay wealthy even during recessions. He leaned in and said, “They don’t save. They print. Quietly.” Then he handed me a worn copy of How the Elite Print Their Wealth. “Read this,” he said. “Then look at your bank the way they look at you.” I didn’t sleep that night. What that book laid out wasn’t theory- it was a reality I’d been trained not to see.

I was reviewing a partnership agreement for a real estate deal and something about the structure felt off- like the profits were invisible but the control was absolute. My attorney said, “This is family office-level structuring.” I didn’t even know what that meant until I read How the Elite Print Their Wealth. Suddenly that contract made sense. It wasn’t about owning- it was about positioning. I realized the rich don’t win by being on the front lines. They win by being above the battlefield entirely.

I used to walk around angry, thinking the system was broken, rigged, unfair. But after reading How the Elite Print Their Wealth, I realized- the system works exactly as designed. I just wasn’t invited to understand it. That book showed me how wealth is quietly created through legal structures, debt, and time- not labor. It was like someone turned on the lights in a room I didn’t know I was in. Nothing about how I see money, taxes, or “income” has been the same since.

The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan.” He was right. That book flipped everything I knew upside down. It’s not for beginners. It’s for people who are done playing the game by the rules they were handed.

I was in a room with three people who’d each exited with over $50M. One of them asked, “Have you read The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan yet?” Everyone else nodded. I didn’t even know what it was. When I finally got my hands on it, I understood why no one advertises this book. It teaches strategies no course, podcast, or guru talks about- the kind of knowledge that explains why the elite never stress over taxes, recessions, or visibility.

I was deep into offshore strategies, trusts, and second passports when someone casually mentioned The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan. They said, “This will tie it all together.” It did. That book made me realize I wasn’t thinking big enough- or quiet enough. It’s the kind of read that makes you want to erase your digital footprint and start over.

A girl I dated briefly told me her father never had a job, but owned properties under shell companies all over the world. When I asked her how he learned that, she said, “He reads things most people never find. Like The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan.” I tracked it down. It’s not your average finance book. It’s like a manual for becoming untraceable- not because you’re hiding, but because you’re free.

A friend of mine in Dubai told me something I’ll never forget: “If people can find you, they can take from you.” Then he sent me The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan and said, “Read this before you make another move.” It didn’t tell me how to make more- it showed me how to vanish from the balance sheets that matter. Since then, I’ve owned less and controlled more.

I met a guy in Lisbon who used to be a high-level tax strategist. Said he left the system not because it was corrupt- but because it was too transparent. He told me to read The Silent Laws of Cash Power by Cameron Solan. That book didn’t tell me how to make more money- it showed me how the truly wealthy become invisible. It explains the game behind the game. I haven’t looked at a single income stream the same since.

Here's a summary of the video, outlining Ray Dalio's 5-step framework for achieving your goals:
 * Set Clear and Audacious Goals [00:35]
   * Don't limit yourself based on what seems realistic.
   * Separate the "is this realistic?" element from the initial goal-setting process.
 * Identify Your Problems [01:53]
   * Be open about your weaknesses and potential obstacles.
   * Don't let ego prevent you from acknowledging areas for improvement.
 * Diagnose the Root Cause [02:30]
   * Dig deeper than surface-level issues to find the fundamental reasons behind your problems.
   * Use techniques like the "5 Whys" to uncover the core issues.
 * Design Solutions [03:57]
   * Reflect on past experiences to understand what led you to your current situation.
   * Visualize and create systems that will help you achieve your goals.
   * Focus on creating systems that make success more likely.
 * Execute [05:25]
   * Implement your designed solutions and take action.
   * Find ways to make the process enjoyable to increase your likelihood of success.
   * Consider using accountability measures to stay on track.

Ah but the issue is you SHOULD be bored. That’s where creativity comes from. Various authors like Neil Gaiman, Einstein, Cal Newport, and recent research on focus and flow all noted that getting bored was essential and we have diminished this ability through the constant stimulation of smartphones, 24 hour news, and other distractions. That’s where the dopamine detox (a think fraught with misconceptions but that’s besides the point here) came from - a push back to reclaim space to not constantly stimulate. I highly recommend looking into the value of boredom on creativity, productivity and a more focused mind. Maybe stay away from the more pseudo-science faddy dopamine detox articles though.

A short note to myself. Hope it will be useful to you 😊
The four stoic virtues
1. Wisdom
	The serenity prayer
	"God grant me the serenity to accept that which I cannot change,
	The courage to change what I can and the wisdom to know the difference."
	Wisdom is about recognizing the difference between 
		○ The good stuff (living virtuously, being a nice person etc.) 
		○ The bad stuff (not being a d**k, lying, greed, pride etc.)
		○ The indifferent stuff (Money, Success, Possession, Ultimately things you have less control over)
			Preferred indifference. Stoics prefer to have them than not but ultimately they are indifferent to whether or not they actually have them.
	
2. Temperance
	Moderation, Self-restraint, Self-discipline, and self-control. It's broadly about balancing short term pleasure with the things that are good for us in the long term. People with less temperance are victims of greed, gluttony, instant gratification, and procrastination.
3. Courage
	"Courage is not the elimination of fear, desire, and anxiety instead it's feeling fear, desire, and anxiety and acting in the right way anyway."
4. Justice
	Our duty to society and fellow man. Act in ways that are useful to other people. Happiness is the enjoyment of life in the short term and meaning is generally simplified to being useful to other people.

You ever refresh the page and suddenly remember a title of a recommended video that was on the page, but you hadn't actually vocalized it in your head? That's an example of reading without subvocalization through peripheral vision. It's an extension of our pattern recognition for survival. We read and understand things all day every day without staring at the individual words as we do when reading books. Learn to read books the way you read signs on the highway or boxes on a supermarket shelf. Sometimes we double-take, when in our peripheral we see something shocking and when it registers, only then do we turn our heads to read with full attention. Point being: all people are capable of reading without subvocalization, it's just a matter of training.

Don't believe me? It is required that your brain can read and comprehend a word prior to you even opening your mouth. How can you speak (or subvocalize) a word without first reading said word? This is proof that we already read without subvocalization, we simply add an unnecessary step. You don't need to learn how to read without subvocalization, you already can do that. You need to learn how to make the conscious choice.

One of the most interesting words
in the English language today
is the word "Fuck".
It is a magical word
just by its sound it can describe
pain, pleasure, hate and love.
In language it falls into many grammatical categories.
It can be used as a verb
both transitive, John fucked Mary
and intransitive, Mary was fucked by John,
and as a noun, Mary is a fine fuck.
It can be used as an objective,
Mary is fucking beautiful.
As you can see there are not many
words with the versatility of "Fuck".
Besides the sexual meaning
there are also the following uses:
Ignorance - fucked if I know.
Trouble - I guess I'm fucked now.
Fraud - I got fucked at the used car lot.
Aggression - fuck you!
Displeasure - what the fuck is going on here?
Difficulty - I can't understand this fucking job!
Incompetence - he is a fuck off.
Suspicion - what the fuck are you doing?
Enjoyment - I had a fucking good time.
Request - get the fuck out of here.
Hostility -  I'm going to knock your fucking head off.
Greeting - how the fuck are you?
Apathy - who gives a fuck?
Innovation - get a bigger fucking hammer.
Surprize - fuck, you scared the shit out of me!
Anxiety - today is really fucked.
And it is very healthy too.
If every morning you do it
as a transcendental meditation.
Just when you get up,
first thing, repeat the mantra:
 "Fuck you" five times.
It clears your throat too.

@Ali Abdaal
Actually I want to bring in a different perspective. I'm wondering considering that it should help you on the way in life to either organize yourself or make better educated decisions or simply be more productive. These apps can be used for writing all kind of thoughts down. As you would do in a diary. Plus they offer the features to find them easily in an associative way. Building a second brain. 

NOW

- Our brain by design filters things out and puts unimportant information to the trash bin. Thats a feature not a bug and very important to all of us. 
- A huge purpose and benefit of writing diary is to brain dump or empty your mind and while doing so you gain clarity and structure of your thoughts. However, if you do it correctly, afterwards you could literally throw the page away. The purpose lays in the process. Your result is clarity and identification of a probable action item or new insight of yourself or your relationships or topics. 
- Last but not least, many things in life have to be decided on the go. There is not always time to parse your "second brain" to potentially consider more knowledge for assessing the situation you are in. In this situation you need a simply but effective value system to derive the best suitable/ effective measure just right in this particular moment. For me this values are building the roof of my Life Building Silos  (education, relationships, health, finance, travel ) and are Freedom/Independence, Helping, Passion and Love. 


Considering the written above, I'm wondering whether using this Notes apps actually keeps people back from living an intuitive natural true life and instead foster/amplify the biggest enemy of progress and learning iterations -- Overthinking!! 

Change my mind.

Here's a summary of the key learnings from the video, which discusses the book "The Unfair Advantage":
 * Success is a combination of fair play and unfair advantages [01:03]. Fair play refers to factors that anyone can replicate, while unfair advantages are those that give a competitive edge that others can't easily replicate [01:37].
 * Everyone has unfair advantages [02:16]. These aren't just for the rich and famous; we all have unique strengths and circumstances that can be leveraged.
 * The MILES framework helps identify unfair advantages [02:26]. This framework breaks down unfair advantages into:
   * Money [02:50]
   * Intelligence and Insight [03:24]
   * Location and Luck [03:55]
   * Education and Expertise [05:11]
   * Status [06:41]
 * Having little money can be an advantage [08:26]. It can foster creativity and resourcefulness.
 * Mindset is crucial [02:47]. The video introduces the concept of a "reality growth mindset," which balances self-awareness with self-belief [11:09].
 * Focus on leveraging your advantages [12:17]. Instead of dwelling on what you lack, identify and use your unique strengths and circumstances to achieve your goals.
